I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the strengthening of 
institutional mechanisms of the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) program 
to expedite the implementation of projects and initiatives.1 National institutional mechanisms will 
be operationalized in each SASEC member country, with expanded functions; and a SASEC 
secretariat will be established in the subregion. For effective operation of these mechanisms, the 
TA  will  also  support  capacity  building  and  knowledge  activities  for  the  planning  and 
implementation of projects and initiatives of the SASEC member countries.2 
 
2.  The TA is not included in any country operations business plan or regional cooperation 
business plan, but is directly linked to the goals and mission of the SASEC vision—SASEC: 
Powering Asia in the 21st Century—to propel the subregion to become Asia’s key growth driver 
by 2025; and to the updated SASEC Operational Plan, 2016–2025, which is closely aligned with 
the strategic thrusts of the SASEC vision.3 The proposed strengthening of SASEC institutional 
mechanisms was discussed and endorsed at the virtual SASEC Nodal Officials’ Meeting (NOM) 
in August 2020. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  In April 2017, the SASEC finance ministers launched the SASEC vision in Delhi, which 
was motivated by the subregion’s impressive growth, abundant natural resources, and rapidly 
evolving infrastructure. The SASEC countries then identified strategic levers—promoting industry-
to-industry links, leveraging resource-based industries, and expanding the region’s trade and 
commerce—to achieve the targets in realizing the vision’s goal of sustainable and inclusive 
economic growth. With this vision, SASEC entered a new phase of cooperation. 
 
4.  The SASEC program is also guided by the updated SASEC Operational Plan, 2016–2025, 
which presents a holistic perspective of where SASEC stands in three areas of cooperation 
(transport, trade facilitation, and energy). The updated operational plan contains a streamlined 
pipeline of 112 proposed projects with financing requirements of about $58.90 billion, of this, 
78 projects have identified financing of about $45.84 billion. The updated operational plan is 
envisaged to spur the interest of member governments and development partners in considering 
SASEC projects in their programming discussions. 
 
5.  In August 2020, the NOM discussed the draft Action Plan of SASEC Initiatives (APSI), 
which  identifies  a  subset  of  projects  in  the  updated  SASEC  operational  plan  for  priority 
implementation during 2021–2023. The APSI contains the SASEC program’s strategic objectives 
and initiatives, which include (i) multimodal corridor initiatives based on the network of SASEC 
road corridors; (ii) sector initiatives, such as energy and trade facilitation measures; and (iii) new 
initiatives addressing the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), such as supply chain mapping and 
leveraging the use of digital technology to enable SASEC build more resiliency and sustainability 
in the long term. The NOM endorsed the strategic directions and approaches of the APSI, 2021–
2023, which will be updated every 3 years. 
 
1  The SASEC program brings together Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Myanmar, Nepal, and Sri Lanka in a 
project-based partnership to promote regional prosperity, improve economic opportunities, and build a better quality 
of life for the people of the subregion. The SASEC program started in 2001 with Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, and 
Nepal as the participating countries. Maldives and Sri Lanka joined in 2014 and Myanmar in 2017. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) website on 
27 November 2020. 
3  ADB. 2017. South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Vision: Powering Asia in the 21st Century. Manila; and 
ADB. 2020. South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Operational Plan, 2016–2025 Update. Manila.

2 
6.  For 19 years, the SASEC program has operated on an institution-light, project-heavy 
format. Its mechanisms for facilitation and coordination, as well as the platforms for discussion 
among members, consist of (i) SASEC nodal officials, who meet at least annually to review and 
provide strategic direction and guidance for cooperation under the program; (ii) working groups 
and subgroups, which meet at least once a year to review project priorities and progress; and 
(iii) the SASEC secretariat, which is based at the Asian Development Bank (ADB) headquarters 
and supported by regional cooperation specialists and focal points in ADB’s resident missions.  
 
7.  The SASEC mechanisms have served the program well as the countries  have the 
flexibility to proceed at their own pace. SASEC TA completion reports have shown that SASEC 
mechanisms and discussion platforms have been instrumental and dynamic in fostering close 
cooperation among members on projects, reforms, and initiatives.4 However, as the program 
faces intensified and increasing new demands and the pursuit of the SASEC vision through the 
updated SASEC operational plan and the APSI, SASEC institutional mechanisms need to be 
strengthened. The enhancements in the existing institutional mechanisms and arrangements aim 
to ensure that the SASEC vision provides a coherent and strategic direction for the SASEC 
program; and that the updated SASEC operational plan and the APSI set the framework, 
guidelines, and priorities for more deliberate planning and accelerated implementation of regional 
cooperation projects. 
 
8.  The TA will enhance the SASEC arrangements for coordinating seamless, multimodal 
cross-border  infrastructure;  and  further  strengthen  the  SASEC  program’s  collective  action, 
knowledge  sharing,  and  policy  dialogue  toward  stronger  connectivity,  more  efficient  trade 
processes, and sustainable energy development. The TA thus supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 
operational priority of fostering regional cooperation and integration,5 and contributes to the 
attainment of several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).6  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  economic  cooperation  and  integration 
between  SASEC member countries,  and  between  SASEC  and  its  neighboring  subregions, 
accelerated (footnote 3). The TA will have the following outcome: the implementation of SASEC 
programs, projects, and initiatives accelerated.7 To measure the achievement of the outcome, 
direct indicators will be used in terms of projects included in the APSI with firm financing 
requirements.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  The four TA outputs will establish an enhanced institutional setup for SASEC. The TA 
aims to improve the existing informal setup where nodal officials have limited power to address 
bottlenecks in their countries. The TA will also put in place measures to ensure extensive 
consultations with relevant agencies are conducted in order to mitigate the risk of delays due to 
 
4  For example, ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance Completion Report: Support for South Asia Regional Economic 
Integration. Manila (TA 7491-REG). 
5  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
6  The  TA  will  contribute  to  SDG  1,  ending  poverty;  SDG  5,  gender  equality  and  women’s  empowerment; 
SDG 7, affordable and clean energy; SDG 8, decent work and economic growth; and SDG 9, industry, innovation, 
and infrastructure resilience. 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
administrative processes. The APSI, once endorsed by the SASEC finance ministers, will provide 
a strong impetus for sustaining the availability of resources for SASEC initiatives.8 
   
11.  Output  1:  Regional  and  national  institutional  mechanisms  enhanced.  The 
enhancements of institutional arrangements will involve (i) recognizing the overarching role of the 
SASEC Finance Ministers’ Meeting (FMM) as an oversight body; (ii) upgrading the role of the 
SASEC nodal officials to become the SASEC senior officials with expanded functions; and 
(iii) establishing SASEC national committees (SNCs) to be headed by the SASEC senior officials.   
 
12.  An  overarching  body  at  the  political  level—the  finance  ministers—is  essential  to 
strengthen the countries’ commitment to facilitating policy change and resource allocation beyond 
project identification. The finance ministers will decide on strategic and policy-related matters and 
provide guidance on the SASEC program’s overall direction. At the NOM in August 2020, the 
nodal officials endorsed a proposal for the SASEC finance ministers to meet regularly—every 3 
years, or more frequently as needed—to demonstrate increased commitment to and ownership 
of the SASEC vision.   
 
13.  The senior officials will provide strategic and technical support to the finance ministers and 
ensure continuity of projects and initiatives in their respective countries. Mechanism for SASEC 
activities differs in each member country but generally it is led by the Nodal Official. Some 
countries have more formal coordination arrangements compared to others, while some have 
broader sector agency representation within their national committees. The senior officials will 
convene SNCs to perform SASEC project planning, programming, and implementation in their 
countries. The establishment of SNCs will depend on each country’s legal arrangements. The 
 
SNCs will comprise senior officials from government agencies involved with SASEC. 
 
14.    The senior officials—the Senior Officials’ Meeting (SOM) as a group—will be accountable 
to the FMM and will perform strategic and operational responsibilities beyond coordination. The 
SOM’s main functions will be to ensure the alignment of the priorities, policies, and operation of 
the program with the SASEC vision, and to recommend new areas of cooperation. The SOM will 
meet at least once a year, and report to the FMM on the progress of the SASEC program.  
 
15.  Output 2: Working groups for program-, project-, and task-related initiatives and 
resolution of issues strengthened. Working groups will continue to focus on program, project 
activities  and  initiatives,  along  sector  and  thematic  or  multisector  lines.  They  may  create 
subgroups for highly technical tasks, as subcommittees, expert groups, or task forces. The 
functions of the working groups will involve the identification, prioritization, implementation, and 
monitoring of SASEC projects and initiatives; and engage with the private sector whenever 
possible. The working groups will meet at least once a year and report to the SOM. The TA will 
(i) support the conduct of meetings of the working groups, subcommittees, expert groups and/or 
task forces; and (ii) develop a pipeline subregional programs and projects endorsed by the SOM 
annually. 
 
16.  Output 3: South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Secretariat established 
and operationalized in the subregion. The subregional secretariat will be set up at ADB’s India 
Resident  Mission  to  serve  as  a  mechanism  for  facilitating  coordinated  planning  and 
implementation of SASEC investment plans, projects, and reforms, in a faster and more effective 
 
8  The updated SASEC operational plan contains 112 projects totaling $58.90 billion, with and without financing. The 
draft APSI, 2021–2023, which was discussed at the NOM and working groups and subgroup meetings in August–
October 2020, contains 70 projects from the SASEC operational plan totaling $27.68 billion. The APSI will be updated 
biannually, and the next update will contain at least 60% of the projects in the SASEC operational plan.

4 
manner—intra-country,  intercountry,  and  subregion-wide.  ADB  has  been functioning  as  the 
SASEC secretariat at its headquarters and has performed the role of regional advisor and lead 
financier of the program. However, as SASEC has expanded and its resources have become 
more diversified, the arrangement requires revisiting. Setting up secretariat functions in the 
subregion will enhance the SASEC program’s performance by bringing its operations closer to 
the people who will benefit from its function. The director of ADB’s South Asia Department’s 
Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division will be its member secretary. 
 
17.  The subregional secretariat will support the FMM, SOM, and working groups in carrying 
out  their  functions;  mobilize  financial  resources  and  technical  expertise  from  development 
partners and the private sector for projects and initiatives; coordinate with other subregional 
programs; provide analytical work for and report to the SOM. The secretariat will also serve as a 
knowledge center to promote knowledge exchange and the exploration of knowledge solutions to 
help the SASEC countries make decisions. This model could attract resources from development 
partners for specific knowledge activities, and for their wider engagement in the SASEC process.  
 
18.  The SASEC subregional secretariat will facilitate efficient coordination of the activities of 
the various SNCs that will be set up, in addition to providing technical and other support to 
meetings of the FMM, SOM, and various working groups.  
 
19.  Output 4: Capacity of South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation member 
countries to plan, implement, and monitor projects and initiatives strengthened. The TA 
will conduct knowledge events, studies, and training courses  to enhance the learning and 
capacities of the member countries in areas affecting the program. Good practices and lessons 
from  other  regional  cooperation  programs  such  as  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Economic 
Cooperation Program (GMS) and Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) will 
also be introduced. The TA will also finance analytical work, which will include knowledge sharing, 
to be held back-to-back with working group and subgroup meetings.9 A limited quantity of 
publications will be printed and made available at the knowledge center.  
 
20.  Knowledge dissemination is being supported by the SASEC web team in ADB. This 
involves maintaining the SASEC website as the repository of information on the SASEC program, 
projects, and events; news on South Asia regional cooperation; and related publications. It will 
also provide a snapshot of intraregional trade in SASEC. The TA will support enhancements in 
the form and substance of the website; and in maintaining and updating its contents and social 
media accounts (Facebook and Twitter), and monthly e-newsletter, with a growing number of 
followers  and  visitors  and  increasing  hyperlinks  to  the  SASEC  website  for  more  detailed 
information. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
21.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6: $300,000 and TASF-other sources: $600,000). The 
key expenditure items are provided in Appendix 2.  
 
 
9 Knowledge sharing events will be held in conjunction with the meetings of the SASEC Customs Subgroup on trade 
facilitation; and the SASEC Power Trade Working Group on renewable energy and energy efficiency technology.

5

23.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions. Consultants will 
be recruited individually because (i) they will operate in different countries; (ii) the timing of the 
engagements will differ between countries; (iii) consultants will work and generate outputs 
independently of one another; and (iv) consultant management will be performed by staff of ADB’s 
Regional  Cooperation  and  Operations  Coordination  Division,  South  Asia  Department.  The 
Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division, together with the staff of ADB’s India 
Resident Mission will manage the consultants.10  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening the Institutional Mechanism of the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation 
Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
